context: Since the numeric result of the 13C-urea breath test is a function of total urease activity within the stomach, it has been suggested to use this test as a quantitative indicator for the density of gastric H. pylori colonisation. Several authors have studied whether a correlation exists between 13C-urea breath test values prior to treatment and the response to H. pylori eradication therapy, and have concluded that the bacterial density, as assessed by urease activity, is an important factor in predicting H. pylori eradication [5–13], although others disagree with this conclusion. Furthermore, it has been suggested that the H. pylori eradication rate of the rescue regimen is higher for patients with a lower 13C-urea breath test value after the first-line treatment. In a previous study, performed several years ago, we evaluated whether a correlation existed between 13C-urea breath test values prior to treatment and the response to the ‘old’ 14-day dual therapy with omeprazole plus amoxicillin or the ‘classic’ bismuth-based triple therapy, and no correlation was observed. Thus, we concluded, at that time, that quantification of this diagnostic method – 13C-urea breath test – was not useful to predict the success or failure of the eradicating therapy. At present, 1-week triple therapy combining a proton pump inhibitor with two antibiotics constitutes the standard care for H. pylori infection treatment, and rescue regimens are frequently prescribed for those failing the first eradication trial. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to evaluate whether pre-treatment 13C-urea breath test value may be a predictor of response to H. pylori when either a first-line 1-week proton pump inhibitor-based triple regimen or a rescue regimen are prescribed as eradication therapy, and to evaluate whether a cut-off point for δ 13CO2 value can predict success/failure with these treatments.
